title: 103_hr358
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress recognizes the risks law enforcement officers face daily, the shift in problems they encounter without increased federal support, their crucial role in combating drugs and crime, the rise in violent crime and drug use, the need for a review of current issues affecting law enforcement, and the importance of studying the role of the Federal Government in supporting law enforcement. A review twenty-five years later would help evaluate current problems affecting law enforcement, including drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and decreased funding. Additionally, a comprehensive study of law enforcement issues, such as the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers, working conditions, and responsibility for crime control, would assist in redefining relationships between the Federal Government, the public, and law enforcement officials. A national commission called the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" is established. The Commission's duties are outlined. The Commission will study and recommend changes regarding law enforcement agencies at all levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, research and training, equipment and resources, cooperation among agencies, government and agency responsibility in solving crime, and the impact of the criminal justice system. The Commission will study cooperation among law enforcement agencies at all levels, government and agency responsibility in solving crime, and the impact of the criminal justice system. They will consult with law enforcement officers, officials, and community leaders nationwide for input on important law enforcement issues. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 25 members, including individuals from national law enforcement organizations representing officers and management. Appointments are made by various leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. Members include individuals with academic expertise in law enforcement, Members of the House of Representatives, and Members of the Senate. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. Members include individuals with academic expertise in law enforcement, Members of the House of Representatives, Members of the Senate, and representatives from federal law enforcement agencies, Department of Justice, and State or local governmental entities. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. Members include individuals with academic expertise in law enforcement, Members of the House of Representatives, Members of the Senate, representatives from federal law enforcement agencies, Department of Justice, and State or local governmental entities. The Comptroller General serves in an advisory capacity and oversees the methodology of the Commission's study. Members select a chairperson upon appointment and receive travel expenses but no additional pay or benefits. Members of the Commission appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President will receive travel expenses and allowances, but no additional pay or benefits. Appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may hire experts and consultants under specific regulations. Federal agencies can provide personnel to assist the Commission upon request. The General Services Administrator will offer administrative support services as needed. The Commission is granted powers under this Act. The Commission, under this Act, has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, delegate authority, obtain information from federal agencies, accept gifts, and use the United States mails. They are also required to submit a report. The Commission established by this Act has the authority to conduct hearings, gather evidence, and submit a report to Congress within eighteen months of its formation. The Commission will dissolve sixty days after submitting the report, and certain sections of previous legislation will be repealed.
